quiz.title: Unit 6: Monopoly (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Characteristics, Revenue, Profit Maximization
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Monopoly Features, Demand & MR, Profit Max, Price vs. Quantity Setting

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a pure monopoly?
questions.explanation: A pure monopoly exists when one firm is the sole seller of a product with no close substitutes, protected by barriers to entry.

questions.question: For a monopolist, the relationship between price (P) and marginal revenue (MR) is:
options: P = MR at all output levels.
P > MR at all output levels.
P < MR at all output levels.
P = MR only at the profit-maximizing output.
questions.explanation: Because a monopolist faces a downward-sloping demand curve, to sell more it must lower price on all units, so MR < P for every unit beyond the first.

questions.question: A monopolist maximizes profit by producing where:
questions.explanation: Like all profit-maximizing firms, a monopoly produces where MR = MC. Unlike perfect competition, P > MR at that output.

questions.question: If a monopolist is producing where MR > MC, it should:
questions.explanation: If MR > MC, each additional unit adds more to revenue than to cost, so increasing output increases profit.

questions.question: A monopolist’s demand curve is:
options: The same as its marginal revenue curve.
The same as the market demand curve.
questions.explanation: Since the monopolist is the only seller, its demand curve is the market demand curve.

questions.question: If a monopolist is earning positive economic profit, in the long run:
options: New firms will enter and compete away the profit.
The monopolist will lower price voluntarily.
Profit may persist due to barriers to entry.
The monopolist will increase output to minimize cost.
questions.explanation: Barriers to entry prevent new firms from entering, allowing monopoly profit to persist in the long run.

questions.question: For a monopolist, marginal revenue is less than price because:
options: The firm is a price taker.
To sell more, the firm must lower the price on all units sold.
The demand curve is perfectly elastic.
The firm faces constant returns to scale.
questions.explanation: Lowering price to sell an extra unit reduces revenue on all previous units, so MR < P.

questions.question: A monopolist will never produce in the:
options: Elastic portion of its demand curve.
Inelastic portion of its demand curve.
questions.explanation: A monopolist maximizes profit where MR = MC. MR is positive only when demand is elastic (|Ed| > 1), so it never produces where demand is inelastic.

questions.question: If a monopolist’s marginal cost is zero, it will maximize profit by producing where:
questions.explanation: With MC = 0, profit max occurs where MR = 0, which is where total revenue is maximized (the top of the TR curve).

questions.question: Compared to a perfectly competitive market, a monopoly results in:
questions.explanation: A monopoly restricts output to raise price above competitive levels, reducing consumer surplus and creating deadweight loss.

scoreMessages.90: Strong grasp of monopoly basics, revenue, and profit maximization.
scoreMessages.70: Good; review MR < P relationship and output/price comparisons with competition.
scoreMessages.50: Fair; revisit monopoly characteristics and profit-maximizing rule.
scoreMessages.0: Needs review: monopoly features, demand/MR relationship, and profit-maximizing output.
